docs.snippet: LEAD: Taking strong action on an issue that has divided his Cabinet and threatens new trade friction, President Bush today named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to special negotiations and possible sanctions if their import...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Taking strong action on an issue that has divided his Cabinet and threatens new trade friction, President Bush today named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to special negotiations and possible sanctions if their import barriers are not lowered. The decision incensed the foreign governments.

headline.main: U.S. CITES JAPAN, INDIA AND BRAZIL AS UNFAIR TRADERS

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH; Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Following a script as stylized and deliberate as Noh drama, the Administration has accused Japan of unfairly restricting imports of three major American products - and cited Brazil and India for three other offenses. The decision was an awkward...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Following a script as stylized and deliberate as Noh drama, the Administration has accused Japan of unfairly restricting imports of three major American products - and cited Brazil and India for three other offenses. The decision was an awkward straddle to placate Congressional protectionists without overly offending the Japanese in particular.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In beating Benfica of Portugal Friday night to reach the championship game in the Marlboro Cup tournament Sunday, the national team of the United States discovered three players who can contribute in its critical World Cup qualifying game against Guatemala in two weeks.
